title: How many people do you know that didn't know that coyote was slang for a human smuggler? - Quora

response.answer_text: (A2A) Not many. This meaning of “coyote” is not on the tip of everyone’s tongue here in the northern Northeast, but most have heard it used in that sense. I live in the Northeastern region of the continental US, right up in the northern tier. We don’t hear about human smuggling very often around here, although I have no doubt that it happens. Nearly all of the illegal migration that occurs in the region is in a northern direction, out of the United States and into Canada. Most of the migrants trying to enter Canada are undocumented individuals and families who have been living in the US illegally. The Canadian government does not like this activity one little bit. They really do not like people entering their country without permission, and this was true even before the border was closed due to COVID. They promptly arrest anyone who they catch, but in contrast to the practice in the US, they treat such people humanely and do not go to extraordinary lengths to torment or terrorize them. The language associated with human smuggling is not a regular part of the vocabulary here. With that being said, most people in this region are aware of the slang meaning of “coyote,” although they may need to pause for a second before they recall it. It is a word that they associate with activity on the Southern (US/Mexico) Border, which is in the southwestern US and thousands of miles away from them. Problems down along that border have been a prominent part of the national news for several years, so even people in parts of the country that are this far north and this far east have been getting informed about them all along. The language of border control issues has accompanied that steady influx of news coverage. So yes, people living along the northern tier of the Northeastern US have been exposed to slang terms like “coyote.” The word normally conjures up images of the wild canid among North Country residents, because that is something they encounter every day. Canis latrans is all the place. But if you make the context clear and give them a second to think about it, residents in this part of the US will recognize that other meaning of the term.

Several that I know had to be enlightened to the meaning of the term. It is used throughout Texas and probably other states bordering Mexico well. We were hunting in south Texas when one of our group was approached by a group of 65 illegals with their Coyote leader. They ran into the brush and waited for us to leave. A border patrol agent showed up and spoke out into the brush. Five of the illegals walked out. The agent strapped each one into a seat belt and waved to us as he left. I asked what just happened since I didn’t speak Spanish. The border agent told them he only had seat belts for five. If five gave themselves up the rest could go. The talked among themselves and five walked out. The most fit five of the group. They would be sent back into Mexico. As soon as they could they would recross the border and rejoin the group and continue north into the USA.

I certainly didn’t know, until I read your question, that “coyote” is slang for a human smuggler. Having looked it up, I’ve discovered that this use of “coyote” is common among people living near the US/Mexican border. I know quite a lot of people, none of whom live in the US or Mexico, let alone in that border region. I can therefore state with some degree of confidence that, out of the several thousand people I know, none of them knows about this specific piece of slang usage. The world is quite a big place, and most of it’s inhabitants don’t live in America. I know - weird, isn’t it?

Probably about 6.5 billion people in Asia, Russia, Africa and Europe…. The term is only known to those that know that crossing the border between Mexico and the USA is a thriving business and that the ones doing this business are often called Coyotes. People smugglers exist in many places, but the coyote term is limited to the US/Mexican border. So either you are a local or you watched movies/TV series that involve border crossing. I’m sure that even in the US the term might not be well known as you go awy from the border states…. you would have to poll people in Montana and Nebraska to get an idea.

I don’t meet people, Thanks to corona virus restrictions been unable to get home for 10 months, will not be able to before next summer at the best, but I do have a dictionary, If it has made it to Oxford, then it is established use, a better indicator than how many of my mates know the term Coyote | Definition of Coyote by Oxford Dictionary on Lexico.com also meaning of Coyote North American informal A person who smuggles people from Latin America across the US border, typically for a very high fee.

Nobody that I know of. I checked around on the internet and the usage is still predominantly what I know - “A woman so ugly or nasty that a guy would rather chew off his arm…” well, you know the rest. There is still the older definition, an acronym that dates back to the 70s, when prostitutes were trying to organize and get better respect for themselves. It didn’t succeed and pretty much fallen off the radar. I rather suspect that the term is regional, primarily along the border of the U.S. and Mexico.

I live in Texas… Everyone I know understands what a “Coyote” is when you are speaking about the Border… The disturbing part of this whole fiasco is the number of people that do not know that slang and also happen to hold political office and have the power to vote over border control and immigration issues

Thanks for the A2A. I have a six year old grandchild who was unaware of the term. As part of a lesson on the USA, we discussed the term, its meaning, and context. He knows what a "coyote" is now, and why it's important to stop human trafficking. The educational pseudo-Lego "Build the Wall" play set was a big hit.  Other than that, no.

Well, for one, me. Based on the context of Trump’s remark, I sort of guessed it. I mean, it was obvious he wasn’t talking about a literal coyote. That said, I had never heard the word used in that way before.

Everyone I know, even peripherally, knows the term “coyote” for a human border smuggler. But then I have lived in SoCal for seven decades. It is part of the common language. I think even my late parents knew the term.

I grew up in a small town in the Southwest corner of Kansas. We had a beef packing plant there. I don't remember not knowing the term. My Mother knows the term, and she was a Housewife and Mother all her adult life.
most people in the sw u.s.a., mexico, and central america would know the word, and when spoken in context, many others would, too.
I live in California. I am pretty sure everyone I know has the knowledge of what a coyote is.
I haven't heard the word used that way and I the only person that I have asked hadn't heard it either. “People smuggler” is used in the UK.
I won’t profess to know what other people know about slang terms. I volunteer in Mexico, so I go there often and have heard the term many times - also in films of course.
No one I know is aware of that. I've know it for a bunch of years however.
Never heard that one. Aren’t all smugglers human, or do you mean someone who smuggles humans?
